values.title: Add test cases for using Detach after using Attach

values.description:
dartsim: add prefix 'modelName/' to child BodyNode before calling moveTo in Attach*Joint, then try to restore BodyNode to its original skeleton if / is detected in child BodyNode's name during DetachJoint

This is a quick hack, but it may help with the self-collide problems observed in [ign-gazebo PR 440](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/440/wip-detachable-joint-system/diff).
values.title: DetachJoint: try to restore BodyNodes to original skeleton

summary.raw:
dartsim: add prefix 'modelName/' to child BodyNode before calling moveTo in Attach*Joint, then try to restore BodyNode to its original skeleton if / is detected in child BodyNode's name during DetachJoint

This is a quick hack, but it may help with the self-collide problems observed in [ign-gazebo PR 440](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/440/wip-detachable-joint-system/diff).
summary.html:
dartsim: add prefix 'modelName/' to child BodyNode before calling moveTo in Attach*Joint, then try to restore BodyNode to its original skeleton if / is detected in child BodyNode's name during DetachJoint

This is a quick hack, but it may help with the self-collide problems observed in ign-gazebo PR 440.

values.description:
The current strategy for determining poses of SDF DOM objects is try to resolve the pose relative to the `relative_to` frame using libsdformat's API (currently `ResolvePose`). This could fail if the passed in DOM object was constructed without a containing `sdf::Model`, in which case, the raw pose will be used.

~~For the joint axis xyz `expressed_in` attribute, only an empty value and `__model__` are currently supported.~~
values.title: [Citadel] Add support for sdformat frame semantics

summary.raw:
The current strategy for determining poses of SDF DOM objects is try to resolve the pose relative to the `relative_to` frame using libsdformat's API (currently `ResolvePose`). This could fail if the passed in DOM object was constructed without a containing `sdf::Model`, in which case, the raw pose will be used.

~~For the joint axis xyz `expressed_in` attribute, only an empty value and `__model__` are currently supported.~~
summary.html:
The current strategy for determining poses of SDF DOM objects is try to resolve the pose relative to the relative_to frame using libsdformat's API (currently ResolvePose). This could fail if the passed in DOM object was constructed without a containing sdf::Model, in which case, the raw pose will be used.

For the joint axis xyz expressed_in attribute, only an empty value and __model__ are currently supported.

values.description:
This PR cleans up internal resources (`EntityStorage` objects for links, shapes, etc) when a model is removed.  This fixes an issue in ign-physics where memory consumption grows indefinitely as models are added and removed. 

I ran a test where I was loading and unloading a set of models using levels in ign-gazebo. This is the memory consumption profile before the fix:
![before.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/291536121-before.png)
This is after the fix:
![after.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/321728942-after.png)
values.title: Clean up internal resources when a model gets removed

I ran a test where I was loading and unloading a set of models using levels in ign-gazebo. This is the memory consumption profile before the fix: This is after the fix:

values.description:
This PR adds support for the collide\_bitmask feature \(present in Gazebo classic\) to disable collisions between sets of objects.

Since I’m quite new at ign-physics there might be a few rough edges and, while it works in my scenario, I’m not quite sure it is either the right approach to do it or whether it works in all cases, I’ll get some more worlds \(like the gazebo classic example one to explain collide\_bitmasks\) in the coming days and double check it works as intended.

A few parts that I’d like feedback on:

* Is this actually the right way to implement such a feature? Again being new at ign-physics it’s quite the learning curve.
* Is the Feature definition correct? Is that the right place to put it? Since it’s a shape feature I thought about adding it to Shape.hh but was afraid about what might have happened if there was a physics engine that didn’t provide it.
* I’m also not very familiar with the DART API so if there is anything obviously wrong there feel free to let me know.
* When populating the hashmap bitmask\_map I noticed \(by adding a print statement\) that even for a moderate number of objects there is a huge number of entries being added, I suspect this is due to using shapes but again I’m not too sure.

‌
values.title: Implement collision filtering based on collide_bitmask property

summary.raw:
This PR adds support for the collide\_bitmask feature \(present in Gazebo classic\) to disable collisions between sets of objects.

Since I’m quite new at ign-physics there might be a few rough edges and, while it works in my scenario, I’m not quite sure it is either the right approach to do it or whether it works in all cases, I’ll get some more worlds \(like the gazebo classic example one to explain collide\_bitmasks\) in the coming days and double check it works as intended.

A few parts that I’d like feedback on:

* Is this actually the right way to implement such a feature? Again being new at ign-physics it’s quite the learning curve.
* Is the Feature definition correct? Is that the right place to put it? Since it’s a shape feature I thought about adding it to Shape.hh but was afraid about what might have happened if there was a physics engine that didn’t provide it.
* I’m also not very familiar with the DART API so if there is anything obviously wrong there feel free to let me know.
* When populating the hashmap bitmask\_map I noticed \(by adding a print statement\) that even for a moderate number of objects there is a huge number of entries being added, I suspect this is due to using shapes but again I’m not too sure.

‌
summary.html:
This PR adds support for the collide_bitmask feature (present in Gazebo classic) to disable collisions between sets of objects.

Since I’m quite new at ign-physics there might be a few rough edges and, while it works in my scenario, I’m not quite sure it is either the right approach to do it or whether it works in all cases, I’ll get some more worlds (like the gazebo classic example one to explain collide_bitmasks) in the coming days and double check it works as intended.

A few parts that I’d like feedback on:

  • Is this actually the right way to implement such a feature? Again being new at ign-physics it’s quite the learning curve.
  • Is the Feature definition correct? Is that the right place to put it? Since it’s a shape feature I thought about adding it to Shape.hh but was afraid about what might have happened if there was a physics engine that didn’t provide it.
  • I’m also not very familiar with the DART API so if there is anything obviously wrong there feel free to let me know.
  • When populating the hashmap bitmask_map I noticed (by adding a print statement) that even for a moderate number of objects there is a huge number of entries being added, I suspect this is due to using shapes but again I’m not too sure.

‌

values.description:
Following the same reasoning as [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/222/unversioned-system-libraries/diff#chg-src/systems/CMakeLists.txt) `ign-gazebo` PR, now that users will be able to pick the physics plugin they want to use, we should offer an unversioned path so that files don't need to be updated for each version.

This PR also installs engine plugins in a specific folder (`.../engine-plugins/`), so that in the future, when we need to crawl this folder to check all available plugins for features, we don't need to go over every single plugin in `/lib`.

I could move this logic to a separate macro, or maybe even add an option to `ign-cmake` (we may want to stop installing all libraries to `/lib` though). For now I just left it inside the `dartsim` code since it's the only place that's using it in `ign-physics`.

With this PR, this is what the install paths look like:

```
$ find install/ | grep dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics-dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1.5.0
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1.5.0
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so
```

This will be used by [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/541/) `ign-gazebo` PR.
values.title: Install plugins to unversioned files

summary.raw:
Following the same reasoning as [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/222/unversioned-system-libraries/diff#chg-src/systems/CMakeLists.txt) `ign-gazebo` PR, now that users will be able to pick the physics plugin they want to use, we should offer an unversioned path so that files don't need to be updated for each version.

This PR also installs engine plugins in a specific folder (`.../engine-plugins/`), so that in the future, when we need to crawl this folder to check all available plugins for features, we don't need to go over every single plugin in `/lib`.

I could move this logic to a separate macro, or maybe even add an option to `ign-cmake` (we may want to stop installing all libraries to `/lib` though). For now I just left it inside the `dartsim` code since it's the only place that's using it in `ign-physics`.

With this PR, this is what the install paths look like:

```
$ find install/ | grep dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics-dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1.5.0
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1

install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1.5.0
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so
```

This will be used by [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/541/) `ign-gazebo` PR.
summary.html:
Following the same reasoning as this ign-gazebo PR, now that users will be able to pick the physics plugin they want to use, we should offer an unversioned path so that files don't need to be updated for each version.

This PR also installs engine plugins in a specific folder (.../engine-plugins/), so that in the future, when we need to crawl this folder to check all available plugins for features, we don't need to go over every single plugin in /lib.

I could move this logic to a separate macro, or maybe even add an option to ign-cmake (we may want to stop installing all libraries to /lib though). For now I just left it inside the dartsim code since it's the only place that's using it in ign-physics.

With this PR, this is what the install paths look like:

$ find install/ | grep dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics-dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1.5.0
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1
install/lib/ign-physics-1/engine-plugins/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1.5.0
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so.1
install/lib/libignition-physics1-dartsim-plugin.so

This will be used by this ign-gazebo PR.

values.description:
Opening PR to get feedback. The features and tests should be working. One question I have is about where the code should live. ~~Currently they are all in Shape.hh but should they be in their own file, e.g. GetBoundingBox.hh?~~ Features now live in `GetBoundingBox.hh`

I noticed and fixed a problem with `contact.sdf` when writing the bounding box test. The sphere radius is specified incorrectly so they all defaulted to a value 1.0.

**Update:** This PR is ready for review
values.title: Add Get Bounding Box features

I noticed and fixed a problem with `contact.sdf` when writing the bounding box test. The sphere radius is specified incorrectly so they all defaulted to a value 1.0.

summary.html:
Opening PR to get feedback. The features and tests should be working. One question I have is about where the code should live. Currently they are all in Shape.hh but should they be in their own file, e.g. GetBoundingBox.hh? Features now live in GetBoundingBox.hh

I noticed and fixed a problem with contact.sdf when writing the bounding box test. The sphere radius is specified incorrectly so they all defaulted to a value 1.0.

Update: This PR is ready for review

Design Doc [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1zU7cVCLcNWlCXwTBnkWIbRUig01Ap6li4hUr-n-kuz0/edit](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1zU7cVCLcNWlCXwTBnkWIbRUig01Ap6li4hUr-n-kuz0/edit) 

TPE Entities

* Engine
* World
* Model
* Link
* Collision
* Shape

TPE FeatureLists

* EntityManagementFeatureList

    * GetEntities 
    
        * GetEngineInfo 
        * GetWorldFromEngine
        * GetModelFromWorld
        * GetLinkFromModel
        
    * RemoveEntities 
    * ContructEmpty
    
        * ConstructEmptyWorldFeature
        * ConstructEmptyModelFeature
        * ConstructEmptyLinkFeature
        
    
* FreeGroupFeatureLis

    * FindFreeGroupFeature
    * SetFreeGroupWorldPose
    * SetFreeGroupWorldVelocity
    
* SimulationFeatureList

    * ForwardStep
    
* RetrieveWorldFeatureList
* SDFFeatureList

    * ConstructSdfWorld
    * ConstructSdfModel
    * ConstructSdfLink
    * ConstructSdfCollision
    
* ShapeFeatureList

    * GetShapeBoundingBox
    * GetBoxShapeProperties
    * GetCylinderShapeProperties
    

‌

values.description:
**Motivation**

Trivial Physics Engine \(TPE\)

1. motivation: we aren't trying to simulate the robots themselves; those are developed by the robot vendors. Instead, we want to simulate and test the higher-order fleet dynamics, sequencing of the elevators and doors, etc.
2. represent entities as 3D points \(x, y, z and roll, pitch, yaw\)
3. no need for continuous Z
4. no need for real physics \(or even real kinematics\)
5. need to detect "conflicts" where bounding boxes/circles intersect, but don't need to model the collisions or contacts in a physically realistic manner

**Goal**

Support fast simulation of 3D \(~2.5D\) world with a minimum set of kinematics related features. It will be interfaced with ign-gazebo, and be loaded as an alternative custom physics engine to `dartsim`.

**Architecture**

TPE Entities \(Entity.hh\)

* Engine
* World
* Model
* Link
* Collision
* Shape\(box, cylinder, sphere and mesh\)

TPE FeatureList

* FeaturePolicy3D
* EntityManagementFeatureList
* SimulationFeatureList
* SDFFeatureList
* ShapeFeatureList

**Implementation Assumptions**

* There is only one engine
* There is only one world per engine
* No constraints 
* No forces or torques
* No canonical link, groupID ~= modelID
* dartsim::shapeID ~= tpesim::\_collisionID
* dartsim::\_boxID ~= tpesim::\_collisionID

‌
values.title: [WIP][Citadel] Trivial physics engine

**Motivation**

Trivial Physics Engine \(TPE\)

1. motivation: we aren't trying to simulate the robots themselves; those are developed by the robot vendors. Instead, we want to simulate and test the higher-order fleet dynamics, sequencing of the elevators and doors, etc.
2. represent entities as 3D points \(x, y, z and roll, pitch, yaw\)
3. no need for continuous Z
4. no need for real physics \(or even real kinematics\)
5. need to detect "conflicts" where bounding boxes/circles intersect, but don't need to model the collisions or contacts in a physically realistic manner

**Goal**

Support fast simulation of 3D \(~2.5D\) world with a minimum set of kinematics related features. It will be interfaced with ign-gazebo, and be loaded as an alternative custom physics engine to `dartsim`.

**Architecture**

TPE Entities \(Entity.hh\)

* Engine
* World

* Link
* Collision
* Shape\(box, cylinder, sphere and mesh\)

‌
summary.html:
Motivation

Trivial Physics Engine (TPE)

  1. motivation: we aren't trying to simulate the robots themselves; those are developed by the robot vendors. Instead, we want to simulate and test the higher-order fleet dynamics, sequencing of the elevators and doors, etc.
  2. represent entities as 3D points (x, y, z and roll, pitch, yaw)
  3. no need for continuous Z
  4. no need for real physics (or even real kinematics)
  5. need to detect "conflicts" where bounding boxes/circles intersect, but don't need to model the collisions or contacts in a physically realistic manner

Goal

Support fast simulation of 3D (~2.5D) world with a minimum set of kinematics related features. It will be interfaced with ign-gazebo, and be loaded as an alternative custom physics engine to dartsim.

Architecture

TPE Entities (Entity.hh)

  • Engine
  • World
  • Model
  • Link
  • Collision
  • Shape(box, cylinder, sphere and mesh)

TPE FeatureList

  • FeaturePolicy3D
  • EntityManagementFeatureList
  • SimulationFeatureList
  • SDFFeatureList
  • ShapeFeatureList

Implementation Assumptions

  • There is only one engine
  • There is only one world per engine
  • No constraints 
  • No forces or torques
  • No canonical link, groupID ~= modelID
  • dartsim::shapeID ~= tpesim::_collisionID
  • dartsim::_boxID ~= tpesim::_collisionID

‌

values.reason: only one PR #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/129  left to merge, no need for record-keeping anymore

values.description:
PR1 according to plan here [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/124/wip-citadel-trivial-physics-engine#comment-140114840](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/124/wip-citadel-trivial-physics-engine#comment-140114840) . It is the first PR that needs to be merged before the rest.

Based on discussion, the TPE is split into `lib` and `plugin` . This PR will ensure TPE is added as component for now inside `ign-physics` .

‌

summary.raw:

values.description:
This allows the features of an entity to be cast to a new feature set \(when possible\) using `auto entity_with_new_features = RequestFeatures<NewFeatureSet>::From(entity)`.

If any one of the features in the requested feature set is missing, then a null `EntityPtr` will be returned.

You can also get a set of the names of which features are unavailable for the entity using `auto missing_feature_names = RequestFeatures<NewFeatureSet>::MissingFeatureNames(entity)`. This set will be empty if all the requested features are available.

I’ve included a few simple tests to show this working.
values.title: Dynamic entity cast

summary.raw:
This allows the features of an entity to be cast to a new feature set \(when possible\) using `auto entity_with_new_features = RequestFeatures<NewFeatureSet>::From(entity)`.

If any one of the features in the requested feature set is missing, then a null `EntityPtr` will be returned.

You can also get a set of the names of which features are unavailable for the entity using `auto missing_feature_names = RequestFeatures<NewFeatureSet>::MissingFeatureNames(entity)`. This set will be empty if all the requested features are available.

I’ve included a few simple tests to show this working.

If any one of the features in the requested feature set is missing, then a null EntityPtr will be returned.

You can also get a set of the names of which features are unavailable for the entity using auto missing_feature_names = RequestFeatures<NewFeatureSet>::MissingFeatureNames(entity). This set will be empty if all the requested features are available.

I’ve included a few simple tests to show this working.

values.description:
* Add documentation
* Renamed `FeatureListT` to `ToFeatureList` to have some symmetry with `FromFeatureList`
* Some style updates
* Moved the test to `test/integration` so it can easily use the mock features and can run without DART
* Added a couple test cases in the end to increase test coverage

values.description:
This doc focuses on a couple of things about Ignition Physics

* brief intro to ignition physics library
* high level concept of how physics plugin works
* explanation of terminology used in plugin implementation
* functional differences between Dart and TPE
* entity and feature comparison between Dartsim and TPE-plugin

The goal of this documentation is to help user choose which physics engine to use, and gain insight in how physics plugins works and is implemented, thus also prepare them to write their own plugin.

‌
values.title: [Citadel][Doc] Dart vs. TPE Documentation

values.description:
The original plugin relied on a few undesired points:

* Dummy implementation of unsupported features, like `ShapeFeature`
* Several changes to `ignition::gazebo::system::Physics` to work around the need for `Construct*` features. But those features are needed by other plugins, and I believe they should be the way we construct links, joints and collisions.

In this PR:

* Install unversioned lib (like pull request #121)
* Remove `ShapeFeatures` since the feature was not implemented
* Change `Build*` to `Construct*` so the features are actually implemented

~~I left `BuildSdfLink` because that requires a `const int _linkIndex`. I tried substituting that with a unique integer generated on the fly, but then the plugin was crashing at runtime. I'm not sure if the crash was because of the changes from `Build` to `Construct`, or the random IDs.~~

**Update**: I fixed `ConstructSdfLink` on ce60570, so now this branch is usable in `ign-gazebo` with [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/573/). It doesn't work well though:

* If there's just a single model in the world, it falls due to gravity like it should
* If there's more than one model in the world, they seem to interfere with each other at startup, but then behave properly. For example, on `shapes.sdf` the shapes initially all gather at the origin, bounce back, and then seem to behave naturally. I think there's something being wrongly initialized.
    ![bullet_implosion.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/657227557-bullet_implosion.gif)
* If there's a joint in the world, the simulator crashes.

---

I also noticed several other problems that could be solved before we merge Bullet in. For example, elements like `<inertial><pose>` and `<collision><pose>` are being ignored when they could be used.
values.title: [WIP] Bullet updates

summary.raw:
The original plugin relied on a few undesired points:

* Dummy implementation of unsupported features, like `ShapeFeature`
* Several changes to `ignition::gazebo::system::Physics` to work around the need for `Construct*` features. But those features are needed by other plugins, and I believe they should be the way we construct links, joints and collisions.

In this PR:

* Install unversioned lib (like pull request #121)
* Remove `ShapeFeatures` since the feature was not implemented
* Change `Build*` to `Construct*` so the features are actually implemented

~~I left `BuildSdfLink` because that requires a `const int _linkIndex`. I tried substituting that with a unique integer generated on the fly, but then the plugin was crashing at runtime. I'm not sure if the crash was because of the changes from `Build` to `Construct`, or the random IDs.~~

**Update**: I fixed `ConstructSdfLink` on ce60570, so now this branch is usable in `ign-gazebo` with [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/573/). It doesn't work well though:

* If there's just a single model in the world, it falls due to gravity like it should
* If there's more than one model in the world, they seem to interfere with each other at startup, but then behave properly. For example, on `shapes.sdf` the shapes initially all gather at the origin, bounce back, and then seem to behave naturally. I think there's something being wrongly initialized.
    ![bullet_implosion.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/657227557-bullet_implosion.gif)
* If there's a joint in the world, the simulator crashes.

---

I also noticed several other problems that could be solved before we merge Bullet in. For example, elements like `<inertial><pose>` and `<collision><pose>` are being ignored when they could be used.
summary.html:
The original plugin relied on a few undesired points:

  • Dummy implementation of unsupported features, like ShapeFeature
  • Several changes to ignition::gazebo::system::Physics to work around the need for Construct* features. But those features are needed by other plugins, and I believe they should be the way we construct links, joints and collisions.

In this PR:

  • Install unversioned lib (like pull request #121)
  • Remove ShapeFeatures since the feature was not implemented
  • Change Build* to Construct* so the features are actually implemented

I left BuildSdfLink because that requires a const int _linkIndex. I tried substituting that with a unique integer generated on the fly, but then the plugin was crashing at runtime. I'm not sure if the crash was because of the changes from Build to Construct, or the random IDs.

Update: I fixed ConstructSdfLink on ce60570, so now this branch is usable in ign-gazebo with this PR. It doesn't work well though:

  • If there's just a single model in the world, it falls due to gravity like it should
  • If there's more than one model in the world, they seem to interfere with each other at startup, but then behave properly. For example, on shapes.sdf the shapes initially all gather at the origin, bounce back, and then seem to behave naturally. I think there's something being wrongly initialized.
  • If there's a joint in the world, the simulator crashes.

I also noticed several other problems that could be solved before we merge Bullet in. For example, elements like <inertial><pose> and <collision><pose> are being ignored when they could be used.

values.description:
This PR should greatly reduce the size and quantity of symbols that get generated by templates, likely by some orders of magnitude. It should also help make the size and quantity of symbols scale much much better \(should be nearly constant \[size\] and linear \[quantity\] respectively now instead of linear \[size\] and squared \[quantity\]\).

I believe this has been the leading cause of slow compilation times, especially for GCC.

I made a simple program [here](https://github.com/mxgrey/test_ign_physics) that instantiates every entity type with every existing feature in `ign-physics`, and using all headers provided by `ign-physics`. Before this PR, using gcc-8 it spent over an hour trying to compile on my XPS15 with no success. After this PR, using gcc-8 it compiles in just under 30 seconds. Clang is significantly better, compiling in 11 seconds after this PR.

There is still some cleanup to do, but I wanted to open this PR so the compilation times of `ign-gazebo` can be tested against it.
values.title: Reduce the symbol load caused by feature templates

summary.raw:
This PR should greatly reduce the size and quantity of symbols that get generated by templates, likely by some orders of magnitude. It should also help make the size and quantity of symbols scale much much better \(should be nearly constant \[size\] and linear \[quantity\] respectively now instead of linear \[size\] and squared \[quantity\]\).

I believe this has been the leading cause of slow compilation times, especially for GCC.

I made a simple program [here](https://github.com/mxgrey/test_ign_physics) that instantiates every entity type with every existing feature in `ign-physics`, and using all headers provided by `ign-physics`. Before this PR, using gcc-8 it spent over an hour trying to compile on my XPS15 with no success. After this PR, using gcc-8 it compiles in just under 30 seconds. Clang is significantly better, compiling in 11 seconds after this PR.

There is still some cleanup to do, but I wanted to open this PR so the compilation times of `ign-gazebo` can be tested against it.
summary.html:
This PR should greatly reduce the size and quantity of symbols that get generated by templates, likely by some orders of magnitude. It should also help make the size and quantity of symbols scale much much better (should be nearly constant [size] and linear [quantity] respectively now instead of linear [size] and squared [quantity]).

I believe this has been the leading cause of slow compilation times, especially for GCC.

I made a simple program here that instantiates every entity type with every existing feature in ign-physics, and using all headers provided by ign-physics. Before this PR, using gcc-8 it spent over an hour trying to compile on my XPS15 with no success. After this PR, using gcc-8 it compiles in just under 30 seconds. Clang is significantly better, compiling in 11 seconds after this PR.

There is still some cleanup to do, but I wanted to open this PR so the compilation times of ign-gazebo can be tested against it.
